name: 1575_A. Another Sorting Problem
description:
Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books. Each book is represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, each with length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:

  * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; 
  * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. 

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4

Each book has a title that is represented by a string of length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds: if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4


-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books, with each book represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n. Each book has a title that is represented by a string of length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending. While Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending, he has a different approach. Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds: if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4

Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books, with each book represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, and each book has a title that is represented by a string of length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds: if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4


-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
completion:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles and store them with their original indices
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def asc_desc_ending_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a key based on the asc-desc-ending order
        key = []
        for i, char in enumerate(title):
            if i % 2 == 0:
                # Odd-indexed (1-based) characters: ascending
                key.append((char, 1))
            else:
                # Even-indexed (1-based) characters: descending
                key.append((char, -1))
        return key
    
    # Sort the books using the custom comparator
    sorted_books = sorted(books, key=asc_desc_ending_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted book titles
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_books]
    
    # Print the result
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()
completions:
def custom_sort_key(s):
    # Create a tuple for sorting based on asc-desc-ending order
    return tuple((ord(c) if i % 2 == 0 else -ord(c)) for i, c in enumerate(s))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:]
    
    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = list(enumerate(titles, start=1))
    
    # Sort using the custom key
    indexed_titles.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[1]))
    
    # Output the indices of the sorted titles
    sorted_indices = [index for index, _ in indexed_titles]
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def custom_sort_key(s):
    # Create a tuple of characters with odd-indexed characters as is (for ascending)
    # and even-indexed characters negated (for descending)
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(s))

    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m

    # Sort the books using the custom sort key

    # Sort titles using the custom sort key

    # Print the sorted indices

    import sys

    data = input().splitlines()

    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles and store them with their original indices
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def asc_desc_ending_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a key based on the asc-desc-ending order
        key = []
        for i, char in enumerate(title):
            if i % 2 == 0:
                # Odd-indexed (1-based) characters: ascending
                key.append((char, 1))
            else:
                # Even-indexed (1-based) characters: descending
                key.append((char, -1))
        return key
    
    # Sort the books using the custom comparator
    sorted_books = sorted(books, key=asc_desc_ending_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted book titles
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_books]
    
    # Print the result
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

       ABC

       BAC

def custom_sort_key(s):
    # Create a tuple of characters with custom sorting logic
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(s))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:n+2]
    
    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = list(enumerate(titles, start=1))
    
    # Sort using the custom key
    indexed_titles.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[1]))
    
    # Output the indices of the sorted titles
    sorted_indices = [index for index, _ in indexed_titles]
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

    # Create a tuple of characters with odd-indexed characters as is (for ascending)
    # and even-indexed characters negated (for descending)
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(s))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles
    books = [(i + 1, data[i + 1]) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Sort the books using the custom sort key
    books.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[1]))
    
    # Extract and print the indices of the sorted books
    sorted_indices = [index for index, _ in books]
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def custom_sort_key(s):
    # Create a tuple that represents the custom sort order
    # Odd-indexed characters are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c)) for i, c in enumerate(s)))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:]
    
    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = [(titles[i], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Sort using the custom sort key
    indexed_titles.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[0]))
    
    # Extract the indices from the sorted list
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in indexed_titles]
    
    # Print the sorted indices
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

Round_0.code:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles and store them with their original indices
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def asc_desc_ending_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a key based on the asc-desc-ending order
        key = []
        for i, char in enumerate(title):
            if i % 2 == 0:
                # Odd-indexed (1-based) characters: ascending
                key.append((char, 1))
            else:
                # Even-indexed (1-based) characters: descending
                key.append((char, -1))
        return key
    
    # Sort the books using the custom comparator
    sorted_books = sorted(books, key=asc_desc_ending_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted book titles
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_books]
    
    # Print the result
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

prompt:
Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books, with each book represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n. Each book has a title that is represented by a string of length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds: if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4
